title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The attainder of Jerviswood was reversed by the Convention Parliament at the Revolution.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Jerviswood, the ancient seat of the illustrious patriot who was murdered under the forms of law during the reign of Charles IL, is about a mile and a half northward from Lanark, on the south side of the Mouse.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: Some Presbyterian gentlemen of the east, away about Fife and Angus-shires, had, it seemed, commissioned arms and ammunition from Holland, and by the very same ship in which Redheugh the younger was to return home ; and the youth, as one well thought on for parts, and courage, and true principles,  had been intrusted with divers papers by Baillie of Jerviswood, and Sir Patrick Home, and others, exiles for conscience and civil liberty,' both touching their private affairs, the sufferings of the realm, and the dawn of a better day.

title: The works of Robert Burns;
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Lord Hailes, in the notes to his collection of ancient  Scots poems, says, that this song was the composition of a lady Grissel Baillie, daughter of the first earl of Marchmont, and wife of George Baillie, of Jerviswood.

author: Burns, Robert

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Lord IIailes, in the notes to his collection of ancient Scots poeras, says that this song was the composition of a Lady Grissel Baillie, daughter of the first Earl of Marchmont, and vrife of George Baillie, of Jerviswood.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: This gentleman had given strong proof of his fidelity and fortitude ;for, being arrested in Charles II.'s time, on account of his connexion with theconspiracy called Jerviswood's Plot, he underwent the cruel torture of the thumbikins, which, as I before told you, were screws, that almost crushed the thumbs topieces.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: But his nephew, Walter, Earl of Tarras, was deeplyconcerned in the Jerviswood Plot; more than one of Harden's sons were alsoimplicated, and hence he became obnoxious to the Government.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: No other person was executed for accession to whatwas called the Jerviswood Plot; but many gentlemen were tried in absence, andtheir estates being declared forfeited, were bestowed on the most violent tools ofthe Government.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: In the meantime, Baillie of Jerviswood, though in a very infirm state of health,was brought to that trial from which Polwarth and others had escaped somarvellously.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Butalthough Campbell of Cessnock, Baillie of Jerviswood, and some conspirators ofless consequence, were arrested, the escape of most of the persons concerned,partly disappointed the revenge of the government.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: A deputation of their number, Lord Melville,Sir John Cochrane, Baillie of Jerviswood, and others, went to London to preparefor this emigration.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The Duke of York's Administration of Affairs in Scotland—Persecution ofthe Cameronians—The Jerviswood and Rye-House Plots—Death of Charles II.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
